Award.AwardTitle: Two-Dimensional Infrared Spectroscopy of the Conformational Dynamics of Biomolecules
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports the research effort of Professor Andrei Tokmakoff aimed at developing the experimental method of two-dimensional infrared spectroscopy (2D IR) for the purposes of visualizing how DNA and proteins change their structure in real time. As important as these processes are in materials chemistry, biomedical research, and nanotechnology, few experiments are currently capable of studying how macromolecules change their structure during the course of chemical reactions and physical processes, since they occur on nanosecond to microsecond time-scales in solution. This work supports two graduate students as they learn about solution-phase chemical dynamics, macromolecular structure, and protein and DNA conformational changes. Additionally, this grant plays a role in supporting two continually expanding online textbooks, "Time-Dependent Quantum Mechanics and Spectroscopy" and "Concepts in Biophysical Chemistry".

The specific scientific objective of this grant is to continue the ongoing development of transient 2D IR spectroscopy. The current method uses a temperature-jump (T-jump) to initiate conformational changes of proteins and DNA, and tracks the resulting changes in molecular structure with 2D IR. First, T-jump transient 2D IR experiments are used to study the conformational dynamics of DNA oligonucleotides, including hybridization, bubbling, fraying, and base flipping. Second, as a complementary approach to T-jumps, nanosecond transient pH-jump methods based on photoacids are developed for transient 2D IR studies of protonation-triggered protein conformational changes. Finally, the research group is continuing their ongoing development of 2D IR to study conformational changes to membrane proteins and lipid bilayers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Under NSF grant CHE-1561888, the Tokmakoff group develops ultrafast two-dimensional infrared spectroscopy (2D IR) for the purposes of characterizing the conformations of biological macromolecules and describing their conformational dynamics. Conformational changes are intrinsic to the function of these molecules, but understanding their dynamics (how they change their structure) at a molecular level remains poorly understood. We use 2D IR as a fast camera with a 10-12second shutter speed, together with modeling and molecular dynamics (MD) simulation to reveal the molecular details of these processes. 2D IR spectroscopy following a nanosecond laser temperature jump (T-jump) allows us to study thermally induced DNA duplex melting and protein conformational changes on nanosecond to millisecond time scales, offering faster time resolution than NMR and more structural information than other optical experiments. 

The scientific activities supported by this grant include: (1) T-jump IR spectroscopy of sequence-specific hybridization of small DNA oligonucleotides, (2) development of a lattice model for modeling DNA hybridization, (3) development of 2D IR spectroscopy and T-jump methods for investigating dynamics of membranes and membrane proteins, and (4) development of fluorescence-detected IR spectroscopy for high sensitivity studies of molecular structure and dynamics in solution.

Our investigations of DNA hybridization are motivated by revealing the dynamic mechanism by which specific contacts between two molecules form during molecular self-assembly. The strategy is based on inferring this process by time-resolving the reverse process of T-jump induced dissociation. Time-resolved infrared spectroscopy allows one to observe the base stacking and hydrogen bonding interactions that result in DNA hybridization. Taken together, our IR experiments and analysis methods provide a new avenue to study the kinetics and dynamics of nucleic acid folding. With this toolbox we investigated the sequence dependence and length dependence of DNA dehybridization kinetics and dynamics.  

2D IR spectroscopy and T-jump experiments were also applied to describe the fast dynamics associated with lipid bilayers and integral membrane proteins. IR spectroscopy of the carbonyl groups ofphosphatidylcholine lipids and protein amide vibrations were used in combination with T-jump triggering methods to develop a picture of fast membrane dynamics. Using a T-jumpto trigger a gel-to-fluid phase transition in lipid vesicles allowed us to monitor in real time how a membrane protein responds by thinning on a nanosecond time scale and the induced structural changes to the membrane protein.

Finally, we directed some of our effort in order to develop new methods for ultrahigh sensitivity IR spectroscopy, with the goal of reaching single-molecule sensitivity. The instrumentation developed include a new 1 MHz fiber laser source for tunable femtosecond mid-infrared pulses, and an FEIR spectrometer based on a confocal epifluorescence microscope. With this instrument, we measured FEIR signals from solutions as dilute as 10 nanomolar, which corresponds to an average of 20 molecules in the probe volume.

Beyond the immediate scientific advances, the broader impacts of this work include the development of human resources and educational material for physical chemists. This grant supported work on projects that involved one postdoctoral scholar, seven graduate students, and one undergraduate student, and resulted in four PhD theses. This grant has helped support the training of all these individuals in the interdisciplinary activities under this project (physical chemistry, laser technology, spectroscopy, molecular biophysics, computational modeling, and properties of molecular condensed matter). Additionally, many of the fundamental topics upon which the funded research is based are being integrated into educational material, including an online textbook on quantum mechanics and spectroscopy (tdqms.uchicago.edu), and a web-based resource for teaching biophysical chemistry (bpc.uchicago.edu).
